qas.question: From what language did Old English borrow some words?
What individuals introduced the Latin alphabet to the speakers of Old English?
Before the introduction of the Latin alphabet, how was Old English written?
After the Norman Conquest, Latin words entered English via what language?
In what year did the Norman Conquest occur?
What contains loan words from Western Europe?

plausible_answers.text: before the ancestral Angles and Saxons left continental Europe for Britain

qas.question: When were words borrowed from the Germanic languages?

plausible_answers.text: when the Anglo-Saxons were converted to Christianity

qas.question: When did English influence Latin words?

context: <b5_0>Old English<b5_0/> contained a certain number of loanwords from <a0_0>Latin<a0_0/>, which was the scholarly and diplomatic lingua franca of Western Europe. It is sometimes possible to give approximate dates for the borrowing of individual Latin words based on which patterns of sound change they have undergone. Some Latin words had already been borrowed into the Germanic languages <b6_0>before the ancestral Angles and Saxons left continental Europe for Britain<b6_0/>. More entered the language <b7_0>when the Anglo-Saxons were converted to Christianity<b7_0/> and Latin-speaking priests became influential. It was also through <a1_0><b8_0>Irish Christian missionaries<b8_0/><a1_0/> that the Latin alphabet was introduced and adapted for the writing of Old English, replacing the earlier <a2_0>runic system<a2_0/>. Nonetheless, the largest transfer of Latin-based (mainly <a3_0>Old French<a3_0/>) words into English occurred after the Norman Conquest of <a4_0>1066<a4_0/>, and thus in the Middle English rather than the Old English period.
